newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia farmers see progress in PM's title plan.
newsitem.headline: Australia farmers see progress in PM's title plan.

text.p: Australian farmers believe a ten-point plan proposed by Australian Prime Minister John Howard to settle native title uncertainties has brought a resolution of the issue closer but miners remain cautious.
Wendy Craik, executive director of the National Farmers Federation (NFF), said on Tuesday Howard's plan was still under close examination.
"It's hard to tell, it's a basis for discussion. But yes I think it's moving closer to a resolution.
"At the end of the day legislation has to be drafted and the devil is in the detail," she said.
The NFF expected that draft legislation would be introduced in the June sitting of Federal parliament with passage of the law expected by the end of the year, she said.
Craik said Howard's ten-point plan, which had not yet been officially released by the PM's department, varied slightly from day to day on exactly how the ten points were covered.

The points involve: validation of all pastoral leases granted since 1994; extinguishment of native title on freehold, residential and commercial leases; denial of Aboriginal negotiating powers over third-party acquisition of urban land; pastoral leases to be upgraded and to prevail over native title rights.

They also involve: Aboriginal access to require current physical connection with land; reduced Aboriginal right to negotiate on mining; no Aboriginal right to negiotiate over acquisition of vacant urban Crown land and a tighter test to be imposed in rural areas; government controls over water management; overhauling of native-title claims process and inclusion of a sunset clause; voluntary but binding agreements to be established between Aborigines and other parties.
Craik said everything depended on interpretation. Some parts of Howard's plan could work very well for farmers, she said.
An example was the proposal that exclusive possession definition maps out areas where indigenous people have not been resident.
This would remove many pastoral leases from the argument, Craik said.
A spokesman for the Minerals Council of Australia said miners were still waiting for the detail of Howard's plan.
"At this point they're just ten points on a piece of paper," he said.

Howard has been attempting to resolve a major dispute between Aboriginals and Australian farmers and miners which followed a High Court decision of last December which ruled in a case involving the Wik tribe that pastoral leases and native title could co-exist.
Farmers have been pressing the Howard government to fully extinguish native title on pastoral leases.
Farm groups have said that native title uncertainty would affect rural production through blockages to farm business.
Negotiations between mining groups and aboriginals over native title have also unsettled or slowed new mine proposals.
